trial_identification.studytitle: Adjunctive Medical Therapy with Oral Silodosin after Shock Wave Lithotripsy of Lower Ureteral Stone: A randomized controlled study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The efficacy of adjunctive medical therapy with daily oral silodosin(4 mg) after Shock Wave Lithotripsy of lower ureteral stone

interventions.interventions: Daily oral 4 mg silodosin for 2 weeks as adjunctive therapy after ESWL of lower ureteral stones

primaryOutcome.timepoint: reported by patients or stone presence and characteristics were diagnosed through x-ray of kidney-ureter-bladder, abdominal ultrasonography, intravenous urography and nonenhenced CT at 2 weeks
stone presence and characteristics were diagnosed through x-ray of kidney-ureter-bladder, abdominal ultrasonography, intravenous urography and nonenhenced CT at 2 weeks

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: recorded by patient diaries for 2 weeks
recorded by patient diaries for 2 weeks
Dizziness,postural hypotension recorded by patient diaries daily for 2 weeks

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Stones were calculated according to the diameter along the ureteral axis, and the size was between 4mm and 9 mm. All patients underwent ESWL were enrolled in the study after providing informed consent.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: urinary tract infections, high-grade hydronephrosis, diabetes, ulcers, or a history of hypersensitivity to a-blockers, ureteral stricture and pregnant women,history of spontaneous stone expulsion, hypotension, or those found to have systolic blood pressure lower than 110 mmHg

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: 60058 No 565 2nd Ta-Ya Rd Chia-Yi city,Taiwan ROC St Martin De Porres Hospital

fundingsource.fundingaddress: 60058 No 565 2nd Ta-Ya Rd Chia-Yi city,Taiwan ROC St Martin De Porres Hospital

ethicsAndSummary.summary: a prospective study to evaluate the efficacy of oral silodosin 4 mg as adjunctive therapy after ESWL of lower ureteral stones
